Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-input Multi-output Cellular Control: Bacterial Type III Secretion as a Model System

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Voigt
0547637

The objective of this research is to develop computational and experimental methods to quantify how a network integrates inputs from multiple sensors and chooses amongst multiple cellular responses. It is often challenging to quantify how signals are integrated because the stimulus that activates a sensor is unknown or difficult to control in culture. In Aim 1, chimeric sensors will be constructed where the kinase activity can be varied using small molecule inducers. Multiple chimeras will be used to determine the underlying logic operations performed by a regulatory network. In Aim 2, a general methodology will be developed to determine how a cell population bifurcates between multiple co-regulated responses. These methods will be applied to the Salmonella regulatory network controlling type III secretion as a model system of multi-input multi-output control. Two educational programs will be developed to train high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in methods to understand and engineer complex biological systems. First, a new core graduate course will be designed to teach techniques from transport phenomena, kinetics, and non-linear dynamics to problems in biology. Second, a diverse student team, including high school students, will be organized to compete in an intercollegiate genetic engineering competition (iGEM), the goal of which is to design and build a synthetic organism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genes are regulated in cells by complex networks of biochemical interactions. The objective of this grant has been to determine the mechanisms by which these networks integrate multiple environmental inputs and coordinate multiple responses. As a model system, we have studied the regulatory network that controls type III secretion in Salmonella. This is a common pathway by which bacteria export proteins.  Employing a method that allows fast reactions to be quantified, we measured how the outputs of two genetic sensors are integrated. We found that the sensors are highly buffered against cross reactions by a mechanism where they negatively interfere with each other's activity. Further, we used fluorescent reporters and flow cytometry to measure how the sensors are integrated by the regulatory pathway. We identified a new regulatory motif that amplifies the expression of proteins to be exported after the type III secretion system has finished being constructed and is functional. Finally, we harnessed this pathway to export recombinant proteins of biotechnological interest, notably spider silk proteins. The broader impact of this work has been in the training of high school teachers as part of the IISME program in California. This embeds high school teachers in research labs with the objective of the development of new lab-based courses. Second, a company (Refactored Materials) was founded based on the export of silk proteins and received series A funding.
